.highlight .il { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer.Long */</style><div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A function is said to be continuous at a point $a$ if the following statements hold:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<ul>
<li>the function $f$ is defined at $a$</li>
<li>the limit $\lim_{x \to a} \space f(x)$ exists</li>
<li>the limit is equal to $f(a)$, $\lim_{x \to a} \space f(x) = f(a)$</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Continuity of a function can also be expressed more compactly by the statement: $f(x) \to f(a) \space \text{as} \space f \to a$</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Some examples of functions with discontinuity at particular points include:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ f(x) = \frac{1}{x^2}, \qquad f(x) = \frac{x + 4}{(x - 1)(x - 8)}, \qquad f(x) = \frac{1}{x - 1} $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can plot these functions to get a better understanding of where the discontinuity lay.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [138]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">f1</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mf">2.0</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">f2</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">4.0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">((</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mf">8.0</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">f3</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">fx1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1000</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">fx2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">fx3</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">figure</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">131</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f1</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x1</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">fx1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f1</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx1</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlim</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylim</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">500</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">9500</span><span class="p">])</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">132</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f2</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx2</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">fx2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f2</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx2</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">133</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f3</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx3</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">fx3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f3</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">fx3</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

rD5addqbmZmZmZnZmDj5MTMzMzOztuDkx8zMzMzM2oKTHzMzMzMzawtOfszMzMzMrC04+TEzMzMz

"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Although <code>matplotlib</code> plots the line without any breaks, we see each graph has a point where the lines blow up and quickly approaches infinity in either the positive or negative direction.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Interestingly, and somewhat confusingly, although the functions above have a point of discontinuity, they are still said to be continuous functions. The key to this difference is that a function must be <em>defined</em> for all values of $a$. Because the functions cannot be defined at particular values of $x$ due to dividing by $0$, the functions are still continuous.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>All polynomials are continuous anywhere in range $(-\infty, \infty)$. Also, any rational function, which has the form $\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$ is continuous everywhere except for when $Q(x) = 0$.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Knowing the continuity of a function helps evaluate limits much quicker. For example, consider the function:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ \lim_{x \to 4} \space \frac{5 + \sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{5 + x}} $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The function is rational, thus we know it is continuous everywhere except when $Q(x) = 0$. Thus, $x \neq -5$ and we can solve the limit directly:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ \lim_{x \to 4} \space \frac{5 + \sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{5 + x}} = \lim_{x \to 4} \space f(x) = f(4) $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ = \frac{5 + \sqrt{4}}{\sqrt{5 + 4}} = \frac{7}{3} $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Intermediate-Value-Theorem">Intermediate Value Theorem<a class="anchor-link" href="#Intermediate-Value-Theorem">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The Intermediate Value Theorem states that if a function $f$ is continuous in a closed interval $[a, b]$ and $n$ is a number between $f(a)$ and $f(b)$ (where $f(a) \neq f(b)$), then there exists a number $c$ in the interval $(a, b)$ such that $f(c) = n$.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The Intermediate Value Theorem can be applied when locating the root of an equation. For example, we can locate the root of the following equation within the interval $[1, 2]$ (should one exist).</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ x^4 + x - 3 = 0 $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Plotting the function first can help us determine if there is a root in the given interval.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [164]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">f4</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">4</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">3</span>

<span class="n">xvals</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">y1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">xvals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f4</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">xvals</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.15</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="s1">'r--'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="mf">1.15</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.15</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="s1">'r--'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlim</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylim</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">

</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It appears the equation does have a root located in the interval $[1, 2]$. We can also show this with the Intermediate Value Theorem, we take $a = 1$, $b = 2$ and $n = 0$:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ f(1) = (1)^4 + (1) - 3 = -1 < 0 $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
$$ f(2) = (2)^4 + (1) - 3 = 14 > 0 $$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Therefore, $f(1) < 0 < f(2)$ and $n$ is a number between $f(1)$ and $f(2)$. We can get a more accurate interval of where the root is located by setting a tighter interval around the location of the root and applying the Intermediate Value Theorem. Judging by the graph, the root appears to be located in the interval $[1.1, 1.2]$, which we can verify by setting $a = 1.1$, $b = 1.2$ and $n = 0$.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [166]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f4</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.1</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">f4</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.2</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[166]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>(-0.4358999999999993, 0.27360000000000007)</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Thus, we now know the root is located in the interval $[-0.44, 0.27]$.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
